Award.AwardTitle: A Unifying Study of the Capacitated Fixed-Charge Network Flow Polyhedron

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of the research proposal is to derive new strong valid inequalities for capacitated fixed-charge networks and build computational methods for their large-scale solution. The proposal suggests an innovative approach for investigating the polyhedral structure of capacitated fixed-charge network flow (CFNF). In particular, strong valid inequalities that exploit detailed network substructures will be developed based on an effective use of the submodularity of flows and the max flow-min cut theorem. This new approach unifies previous work done on CFNF through a systematic study, which is more generally applicable. Moreover, it allows the derivation of much stronger valid inequalities than known to date, as it uses crucial structural information that has not been exploited yet.

If successful, the fundamental development and solution methods that will result from this project will improve the solvability of large-scale instances of a broad class of logistics, supply chain, telecom applications that contain fixed-charge network flow substructure. One of the immediate outcomes of the project is the development of stronger cutting planes for mixed integer programming software systems that utilize fixed-charge network substructures. These new, strong inequalities can immediately replace the weak ones currently in use to improve the performance of these software systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Capacitated fixed-charge network flows (CFNF) are used to model a variety of problems in facility location, production planning and supply chain management. This research project investigates three-partition as well path relaxations of CFNF to derive new, strong valid inequalities that can be used as cutting planes to solve CFNF problems in branch-and-cut algorithms. These two relaxations are complementary generalizations of the single node relaxations.  There are numerous polyhedral studies on the fixed-charge network flow problem. However, few give explicit valid inequalities that simultaneously  make use of the path and three-partition substructures of the network as well as the arc capacities.In both cases we discovered new valid inequalities that generalize and strengthen the well-known flow cover inequalities from single node relaxations. We give polynomial algorithms to characterize the coefficients of the inequalities explicitly. In particular for the path inequalities, all coefficients can be computed in linear time by a specialized max-flow/min-cut algorithm on the path. We also give polynomial separation algorithms to find inequalities that are violated by a point in a relaxation. Moreover, we give superadditive lifting techniques to further strengthen and generalize the inequalities. Computational experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the new inequalities when used as cuts to solve CFNF problems.
